name: Paramount
Critic Review: Bing Crosby and Barry Fitzgerald are eminently likable, and film is pleasantly sentimental, but Going My Way suffers from a surplus of sweetness.

name: 20th Century-Fox
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Paramount
Critic Review: Director Billy Wilder's unflinchingly honest look at the effects of alcoholism may have had some of its impact blunted by time, but it remains a powerful and remarkably prescient film.

name: Samuel Goldwyn Productions
film: The Best Years of Our Lives
Critic Review: An engrossing look at the triumphs and travails of war veterans, The Best Years of Our Lives is concerned specifically with the aftermath of World War II, but its messages speak to the overall American experience.

name: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: 20th Century-Fox
Critic Review: It occasionally fails to live up to its subject matter -- and is perhaps an 'important' film more than a 'great' one -- but the performances from Gregory Peck and Dorothy McGuire are superb.

name: J. Arthur Rank-Cineguild
Critic Review: Furnished with striking visual detail and told with great narrative economy by director David Lean, Great Expectations is an exemplary adaptation of Charles Dickens' dense and episodic novel.

name: J. Arthur Rank-Two Cities Films
Critic Review: A well-executed labor of love from star and director Laurence Olivier, Hamlet not only proved that Shakespeare could be successfully adapted to the big screen, it paved the way for further cinematic interpretations.

name: Warner Bros.
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Warner Bros.
film: The Treasure of the Sierra Madre
Critic Review: Remade but never duplicated, this darkly humorous morality tale represents John Huston at his finest.

name: Robert Rossen Productions
Critic Review: Broderick Crawford is spellbinding as politician Willie Stark in director Robert Rossen's adaptation of the Robert Penn Warren novel about the corrosive effects of power on the human soul.

name: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Paramount
Critic Review: Arguably the greatest movie about Hollywood, Billy Wilder's masterpiece Sunset Boulevard is a tremendously entertaining combination of noir, black comedy, and character study.

name: Arthur Freed, Producer
Critic Review: The plot may be problematic, but such concerns are rendered superfluous by Gene Kelly and Leslie Caron's star power, the Gershwins' classic songs, and Vincente Minnelli's colorful, sympathetic direction.

name: George Stevens, Producer
Critic Review: Director George Stevens' stately treatment of A Place in the Sun buffs out some of the novel's nuance with blunt moralizing, but riveting performances by Montgomery Clift and company give the drama a bruising punch.

name: Cecil B. DeMille, Producer
Critic Review: The Greatest Show on Earth is melodramatic, short on plot, excessively lengthy and bogged down with clichés, but not without a certain innocent charm.

name: Romulus Films
Critic Review: A love-it-or-hate-it experience, Moulin Rouge is all style, all giddy, over-the-top spectacle. But it's also daring in its vision and wildly original.

name: Martin Brown, Baz Luhrmann and Fred Baron, Producers
Critic Review: A love-it-or-hate-it experience, Moulin Rouge is all style, all giddy, over-the-top spectacle. But it's also daring in its vision and wildly original.

name: John Ford and Merian C. Cooper, Producers
Critic Review: Director John Ford and star John Wayne depart the Western for the Irish countryside, and the result is a beautifully photographed, often comedic romance.

name: Buddy Adler, Producer
Critic Review: It has perhaps aged poorly, but this languidly paced WWII romance remains an iconic, well-acted film, featuring particularly strong performances from Burt Lancaster and Montgomery Clift.

name: Frank Ross, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: George Stevens, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Sam Spiegel, Producer
Critic Review: With his electrifying performance in Elia Kazan's thought-provoking, expertly constructed melodrama, Marlon Brando redefined the possibilities of acting for film and helped permanently alter the cinematic landscape.

name: Sol C. Siegel, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Harold Hecht, Producer
Critic Review: Scriptwriter Paddy Chayefsky's solid dialogue is bolstered by strong performances from Ernest Borgnine and Betsy Blair in this appealingly low-key character study.

name: Fred Kohlmar, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Hal B. Wallis, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Michael Todd, Producer
Critic Review: It's undeniably shallow, but its cheerful lack of pretense -- as well as its grand scale and star-stuffed cast -- help make Around the World in 80 Days charmingly light-hearted entertainment.

name: Charles Brackett, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Sam Spiegel, Producer
film: The Bridge on the River Kwai
Critic Review: This complex war epic asks hard questions, resists easy answers, and boasts career-defining work from star Alec Guinness and director David Lean.

name: Jerry Wald, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Henry Fonda and Reginald Rose, Producers
Critic Review: Sidney Lumet's feature debut is a superbly written, dramatically effective courtroom thriller that rightfully stands as a modern classic.

name: Warner Bros.
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Stanley Kramer, Producer
Critic Review: An advocacy drama that makes its points without belaboring them, The Defiant Ones relies on its clever concept and brilliant performances to repudiate racial prejudice.

name: Arthur Freed, Producer
Critic Review: It may not be one of Vincente Minnelli's best, but the charming and flawlessly acted Gigi still offers enough visual and musical treats to satisfy.

name: Otto Preminger, Producer
Critic Review: One of cinema's greatest courtroom dramas, Anatomy of a Murder is tense, thought-provoking, and brilliantly acted, with great performances from James Stewart and George C. Scott.

name: Sam Zimbalist, Producer
Critic Review: Uneven, but in terms of epic scope and grand spectacle, Ben-Hur still ranks among Hollywood's finest examples of pure entertainment.

name: George Stevens, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: John Wayne, Producer
Critic Review: John Wayne proves to be less compelling behind the camera than he is before it in The Alamo, a blustery dramatization of the fort's last stand that feels more like a first draft.

name: Billy Wilder, Producer
Critic Review: Director Billy Wilder's customary cynicism is leavened here by tender humor, romance, and genuine pathos.

name: Jerry Wald, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Carl Foreman, Producer
Critic Review: Bolstered by a cast of memorable stars and an impressive sense of scale, The Guns of the Navarone fires with vivid characterization and entertaining spectacle.

name: Robert Rossen, Producer
Critic Review: Paul Newman and Jackie Gleason give iconic performances in this dark, morally complex tale of redemption.

name: Robert Wise, Producer
Critic Review: Steven Spielberg's West Side Story presents a new look at the classic musical that lives up to its beloved forebear -- and in some respects might even surpass it.

name: Steven Spielberg and Kristie Macosko Krieger, Producers
Critic Review: Steven Spielberg's West Side Story presents a new look at the classic musical that lives up to its beloved forebear -- and in some respects might even surpass it.

name: Sam Spiegel, Producer
Critic Review: The epic of all epics, Lawrence of Arabia cements director David Lean's status in the filmmaking pantheon with nearly four hours of grand scope, brilliant performances, and beautiful cinematography.

name: Darryl F. Zanuck, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Aaron Rosenberg, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Walter Wanger, Producer
Critic Review: Cleopatra is a lush, ostentatious, endlessly eye-popping epic that sags collapses from a (and how could it not?) four-hour runtime.

name: Tony Richardson, Producer
Critic Review: A frantic, irreverent adaptation of the novel, bolstered by Albert Finney's courageous performance and arresting visuals.

name: Hal B. Wallis, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Jack L. Warner, Producer
Critic Review: George Cukor's elegant, colorful adaptation of the beloved stage play is elevated to new heights thanks to winning performances by Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison.

name: Michael Cacoyannis, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Carlo Ponti, Producer
Critic Review: It may not be the best of David Lean's epics, but Dr. Zhivago is still brilliantly photographed and sweepingly romantic.

name: Stanley Kramer, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Robert Wise, Producer
Critic Review: Unapologetically sweet and maybe even a little corny, The Sound of Music will win over all but the most cynical filmgoers with its classic songs and irresistible warmth.

name: Fred Zinnemann, Producer
Critic Review: Solid cinematography and enjoyable performances from Paul Scofield and Robert Shaw add a spark to this deliberately paced adaptation of the Robert Bolt play.

name: Ernest Lehman, Producer
Critic Review: Led by a volcanic performance from Elizabeth Taylor, Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? is a scathing adaptation of the Edward Albee play that serves as a brilliant calling card for debuting director Mike Nichols.

name: Warren Beatty, Producer
Critic Review: A paradigm-shifting classic of American cinema, Bonnie and Clyde packs a punch whose power continues to reverberate through thrillers decades later.

name: Arthur P. Jacobs, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Lawrence Turman, Producer
Critic Review: The music, the performances, the precision in capturing the post-college malaise -- The Graduate's coming-of-age story is indeed one for the ages.

name: Walter Mirisch, Producer
film: In the Heat of the Night
Critic Review: Tense, funny, and thought-provoking all at once, and lifted by strong performances from Sydney Poitier and Rod Steiger, director Norman Jewison's look at murder and racism in small-town America continues to resonate today.

name: Martin Poll, Producer
Critic Review: Sharper and wittier than your average period piece, The Lion in Winter is a tale of palace intrigue bolstered by fantastic performances from Peter O'Toole, Katharine Hepburn, and Anthony Hopkins in his big-screen debut.

name: John Woolf, Producer
Critic Review: Oliver! transforms Charles Dickens' muckraking novel into a jaunty musical Victorian fairytale, buoyed by Ron Moody's charming star turn and Onna White's rapturous choreography.

name: Anthony Havelock-Allan and John Brabourne, Producers
Critic Review: The solid leads and arresting visuals make a case for Zeffirelli's Romeo and Juliet as the definitive cinematic adaptation of the play.

name: Hal B. Wallis, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: John Foreman, Producer
film: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid
Critic Review: With its iconic pairing of Paul Newman and Robert Redford, jaunty screenplay and Burt Bacharach score, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid has gone down as among the defining moments in late-'60s American cinema.

name: Ernest Lehman, Producer
Critic Review: Though Streisand charms, she's miscast as the titular middle-aged widow in Gene Kelly's sluggish and over-produced final directorial effort.

name: Jerome Hellman, Producer
Critic Review: John Schlesinger's gritty, unrelentingly bleak look at the seedy underbelly of urban American life is undeniably disturbing, but Dustin Hoffman and Jon Voight's performances make it difficult to turn away.

name: Howard G. Minsky, Producer
Critic Review: Earnest and determined to make audiences swoon, Love Story is an unabashed tearjerker that will capture hearts when it isn't inducing eye rolls.

name: Ingo Preminger, Producer
Critic Review: Bold, timely, subversive, and above all funny, M*A*S*H remains a high point in Robert Altman's distinguished filmography.

name: Frank McCarthy, Producer
Critic Review: George C. Scott's sympathetic, unflinching portrayal of the titular general in this sprawling epic is as definitive as any performance in the history of American biopics.

name: Norman Jewison, Producer
Critic Review: A bird may love a fish -- and musical fans will love this adaptation of Fiddler on the Roof, even if it isn't quite as transcendent as the long-running stage version.

name: Philip D'Antoni, Producer
Critic Review: Realistic, fast-paced and uncommonly smart, The French Connection is bolstered by stellar performances by Gene Hackman and Roy Scheider, not to mention William Friedkin's thrilling production.

name: Stephen J. Friedman, Producer
Critic Review: Making excellent use of its period and setting, Peter Bogdanovich's small town coming-of-age story is a sad but moving classic filled with impressive performances.

name: Cy Feuer, Producer
Critic Review: Great performances and evocative musical numbers help Cabaret secure its status as a stylish, socially conscious classic.

name: Albert S. Ruddy, Producer
Critic Review: One of Hollywood's greatest critical and commercial successes, The Godfather gets everything right; not only did the movie transcend expectations, it established new benchmarks for American cinema.

name: Francis Ford Coppola, Producer;  Gary Kurtz, Co-Producer
Critic Review: One of the most influential of all teen films, American Graffiti is a funny, nostalgic, and bittersweet look at a group of recent high school grads' last days of innocence.

name: Ingmar Bergman, Producer
Critic Review: Visually stunning and achingly performed, Ingmar Bergman's chamber piece is a visceral rumination on death and sisterhood.

name: William Peter Blatty, Producer
Critic Review: The Exorcist rides its supernatural theme to magical effect, with remarkable special effects and an eerie atmosphere, resulting in one of the scariest films of all time.

name: Tony Bill, Michael Phillips and Julia Phillips, Producers
Critic Review: Paul Newman, Robert Redford, and director George Roy Hill prove that charm, humor, and a few slick twists can add up to a great film.

name: Robert Evans, Producer
Critic Review: As bruised and cynical as the decade that produced it, this noir classic benefits from Robert Towne's brilliant screenplay, director Roman Polanski's steady hand, and wonderful performances from Jack Nicholson and Faye Dunaway.

name: Irwin Allen, Producer
Critic Review: Although it is not consistently engaging enough to fully justify its towering runtime, The Towering Inferno is a blustery spectacle that executes its disaster premise with flair.

name: Stanley Kubrick, Producer
Critic Review: Cynical, ironic, and suffused with seductive natural lighting, Barry Lyndon is a complex character piece of a hapless man doomed by Georgian society.

name: Robert F. Blumofe and Harold Leventhal, Producers
Critic Review: Bound for Glory brings the Dust Bowl era to authentic life thanks to Haskell Wexler's opulent cinematography and Woody Guthrie's resonant music, capturing the American mood at the time as much as it does the folk singer's life.

name: Irwin Winkler and Robert Chartoff, Producers
Critic Review: This story of a down-on-his-luck boxer is thoroughly predictable, but Sylvester Stallone's script and stunning performance in the title role brush aside complaints.

name: Charles H. Joffe, Producer
Critic Review: Filled with poignant performances and devastating humor, Annie Hall represents a quantum leap for Woody Allen and remains an American classic.

name: Ray Stark, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Herbert Ross and Arthur Laurents, Producers
Critic Review: The Turning Point is a handsomely-made resuscitation of Old Hollywood melodramas with a compelling duo at its center, but the formulaic script keeps this story from realizing its symphonic potential.

name: Barry Spikings, Michael Deeley, Michael Cimino and John Peverall, Producers
Critic Review: Its greatness is blunted by its length and one-sided point of view, but the film's weaknesses are overpowered by Michael Cimino's sympathetic direction and a series of heartbreaking performances from Robert De Niro, Meryl Streep, and Christopher Walken.

name: Warren Beatty, Producer
Critic Review: A throwback to the high-gloss screwball comedies of the 1940s, Heaven Can Wait beguiles with seamless production values and great comic relief from Charles Grodin and Dianne Cannon.

name: Alan Marshall and David Puttnam, Producers
Critic Review: Raw and unrelenting, Midnight Express is riveting in its realistic depiction of incarceration -- mining pathos from the simple act of enduring hardship.

name: Francis Coppola, Producer;  Fred Roos, Gray Frederickson and Tom Sternberg, Co-Producers
Critic Review: Francis Ford Coppola's haunting, hallucinatory Vietnam War epic is cinema at its most audacious and visionary.

name: Peter Yates, Producer
Critic Review: At once a touching, funny coming-of-age story and a compelling sports film, Breaking Away is a delightful treat.

name: Stanley R. Jaffe, Producer
Critic Review: The divorce subject isn't as shocking, but the film is still a thoughtful, well-acted drama that resists the urge to take sides or give easy answers.

name: Bernard Schwartz, Producer
Critic Review: Like a classic traditional country song, Coal Miner's Daughter draws on time-tested formula -- and undeniable talent -- to tell a solidly affecting story.

name: Ronald L. Schwary, Producer
Critic Review: Robert Redford proves himself a filmmaker of uncommon emotional intelligence with Ordinary People, an auspicious debut that deftly observes the fractioning of a family unit through a quartet of superb performances.

name: Claude Berri, Producer;  Timothy Burrill, Co-Producer
Critic Review: A reverent adaptation of Thomas Hardy's novel, Tess marries painterly cinematography and unhurried pacing to create an epic ode to perseverance.

name: David Puttnam, Producer
Critic Review: Decidedly slower and less limber than the Olympic runners at the center of its story, Chariots of Fire nevertheless makes effectively stirring use of its spiritual and patriotic themes.

name: Bruce Gilbert, Producer
Critic Review: Henry Fonda and Katherine Hepburn are a wondrous duo in On Golden Pond, a wistful drama that movingly explores the twilight years of a loving marriage.

name: Warren Beatty, Producer
Critic Review: Brawny in both intellect and scope, Reds is an intimate epic that captures the tumult of revolutionary change and the passion of those navigating through it.

name: Richard Attenborough, Producer
Critic Review: Director Richard Attenborough is typically sympathetic and sure-handed, but it's Ben Kingsley's magnetic performance that acts as the linchpin for this sprawling, lengthy biopic.

name: Sydney Pollack and Dick Richards, Producers
Critic Review: Tootsie doesn't squander its high-concept comedy premise with fine dialogue and sympathetic treatment of the characters.

name: Michael Shamberg, Producer
Critic Review: The Big Chill captures a generation's growing ennui with a terrific cast, a handful of perceptive insights, and one of the decade's best film soundtracks.

name: James L. Brooks, Producer
Critic Review: A classic tearjerker, Terms of Endearment isn't shy about reaching for the heartstrings -- but is so well-acted and smartly scripted that it's almost impossible to resist.

name: Saul Zaentz, Producer
Critic Review: Amadeus' liberties with history may rankle some, but the creative marriage of Miloš Forman and Peter Shaffer yields a divinely diabolical myth of genius and mediocrity, buoyed by inspired casting and Mozart's rapturous music.

name: David Puttnam, Producer
Critic Review: Artfully composed, powerfully acted, and fueled by a powerful blend of anger and empathy, The Killing Fields is a career-defining triumph for director Roland Joffé and a masterpiece of cinema.

name: Sydney Pollack, Producer
Critic Review: Though lensed with stunning cinematography and featuring a pair of winning performances from Meryl Streep and Robert Redford, Out of Africa suffers from excessive length and glacial pacing.

name: John Foreman, Producer
Critic Review: Disturbing and sardonic, Prizzi's Honor excels at black comedy because director John Huston and his game ensemble take the farce deadly seriously.

name: Robert Greenhut, Producer
Critic Review: Smart, tender, and funny in equal measure, Hannah and Her Sisters is one of Woody Allen's finest films.

name: Fernando Ghia and David Puttnam, Producers
Critic Review: The Mission is a well-meaning epic given delicate heft by its sumptuous visuals and a standout score by Ennio Morricone, but its staid presentation never stirs an emotional investment in its characters.

name: Arnold Kopelson, Producer
Critic Review: Informed by director Oliver Stone's personal experiences in Vietnam, Platoon forgoes easy sermonizing in favor of a harrowing, ground-level view of war, bolstered by no-holds-barred performances from Charlie Sheen and Willem Dafoe.

name: John Boorman, Producer
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Jeremy Thomas, Producer
Critic Review: While Bernardo Bertolucci's decadent epic never quite identifies the dramatic pulse of its protagonist, stupendous visuals and John Lone's ability to make passivity riveting give The Last Emperor a rarified grandeur.

name: Frederick Zollo and Robert F. Colesberry, Producers
Critic Review: Mississippi Burning draws on real-life tragedy to impart a worthy message with the measured control of an intelligent drama and the hard-hitting impact of a thriller.

name: Mark Johnson, Producer
Critic Review: This road-trip movie about an autistic savant and his callow brother is far from seamless, but Barry Levinson's direction is impressive, and strong performances from Tom Cruise and Dustin Hoffman add to its appeal.

name: Douglas Wick, Producer
Critic Review: A buoyant corporate Cinderella story, Working Girl has the right cast, right story, and right director to make it all come together.

name: A. Kitman Ho and Oliver Stone, Producers
film: Born on the Fourth of July
Critic Review: Led by an unforgettable performance from Tom Cruise, Born on the Fourth of July finds director Oliver Stone tackling thought-provoking subject matter with ambitious élan.

name: Richard D. Zanuck and Lili Fini Zanuck, Producers
Critic Review: While it's fueled in part by outdated stereotypes, Driving Miss Daisy takes audiences on a heartwarming journey with a pair of outstanding actors.

name: Jim Wilson and Kevin Costner, Producers
Critic Review: Dances with Wolves suffers from a simplistic view of the culture it attempts to honor, but the end result remains a stirring western whose noble intentions are often matched by its epic grandeur.

name: Francis Ford Coppola, Producer
Critic Review: The final installment of The Godfather saga recalls its predecessors' power when it's strictly business, but underwhelming performances and confused tonality brings less closure to the Corleone story.

name: Don Hahn, Producer
Critic Review: Enchanting, sweepingly romantic, and featuring plenty of wonderful musical numbers, Beauty and the Beast is one of Disney's most elegant animated offerings.

name: Mark Johnson, Barry Levinson and Warren Beatty, Producers
Critic Review: Stylishly scattered, Bugsy offers cinematic homage to the infamous underworld legend, chiefly through a magnetic performance from Warren Beatty in the title role.

name: A. Kitman Ho and Oliver Stone, Producers
Critic Review: As history, Oliver Stone's JFK is dubious, but as filmmaking it's electric, cramming a ton of information and excitement into its three-hour runtime and making great use of its outstanding cast.

name: Barbra Streisand and Andrew Karsch, Producers
Critic Review: Although the central romance arguably suffocates the heart of the drama, a moving performance by Nick Nolte and Barbra Streisand's deft direction give The Prince of Tides a soulful edge.

name: Edward Saxon, Kenneth Utt and Ron Bozman, Producers
Critic Review: Director Jonathan Demme's smart, taut thriller teeters on the edge between psychological study and all-out horror, and benefits greatly from stellar performances by Anthony Hopkins and Jodie Foster.

name: Martin Brest, Producer
Critic Review: It might soar on Al Pacino's performance more than the drama itself, but what a performance it is -- big, bold, occasionally over-the-top, and finally giving the Academy pause to award the star his first Oscar.

name: Clint Eastwood, Producer
Critic Review: As both director and star, Clint Eastwood strips away decades of Hollywood varnish applied to the Wild West, and emerges with a series of harshly eloquent statements about the nature of violence.

name: Steven Spielberg, Gerald R. Molen and Branko Lustig, Producers
Critic Review: Schindler's List blends the abject horror of the Holocaust with Steven Spielberg's signature tender humanism to create the director's dramatic masterpiece.

name: Wendy Finerman, Steve Tisch and Steve Starkey, Producers
Critic Review: Forrest Gump may be an overly sentimental film with a somewhat problematic message, but its sweetness and charm are usually enough to approximate true depth and grace.

name: George Miller, Doug Mitchell and Bill Miller, Producers
Critic Review: The rare family-friendly feature with a heart as big as its special effects budget, Babe offers timeless entertainment for viewers of all ages.

name: Mel Gibson, Alan Ladd, Jr. and Bruce Davey, Producers
Critic Review: Distractingly violent and historically dodgy, Mel Gibson's Braveheart justifies its epic length by delivering enough sweeping action, drama, and romance to match its ambition.

name: Lindsay Doran, Producer
Critic Review: Sense and Sensibility is an uncommonly deft, very funny Jane Austen adaptation, marked by Emma Thompson's finely tuned performance.

name: Saul Zaentz, Producer
Critic Review: Though it suffers from excessive length and ambition, director Minghella's adaptation of the Michael Ondaatje novel is complex, powerful, and moving.

name: James L. Brooks, Bridget Johnson and Kristi Zea, Producers
Critic Review: James L. Brooks and Jack Nicholson, doing what they do best, combine smart dialogue and flawless acting to squeeze fresh entertainment value out of the romantic-comedy genre.

name: James Cameron and Jon Landau, Producers
Critic Review: A mostly unqualified triumph for James Cameron, who offers a dizzying blend of spectacular visuals and old-fashioned melodrama.

name: Steven Spielberg, Ian Bryce, Mark Gordon and Gary Levinsohn, Producers
Critic Review: Anchored by another winning performance from Tom Hanks, Steven Spielberg's unflinchingly realistic war film virtually redefines the genre.

name: David Parfitt, Donna Gigliotti, Harvey Weinstein, Edward Zwick and Marc Norman, Producers
Critic Review: Endlessly witty, visually rapturous, and sweetly romantic, Shakespeare in Love is a delightful romantic comedy that succeeds on nearly every level.

name: Bruce Cohen and Dan Jinks, Producers
Critic Review: Flawlessly cast and brimming with dark, acid wit, American Beauty is a smart, provocative high point of late '90s mainstream Hollywood film.

name: David Brown, Kit Golden and Leslie Holleran, Producers
Critic Review: Chocolat is a charmingly light-hearted fable with a lovely performance by Binoche.

name: Bill Kong, Hsu Li Kong and Ang Lee, Producers
Critic Review: The movie that catapulted Ang Lee into the ranks of upper echelon Hollywood filmmakers, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon features a deft mix of amazing martial arts battles, beautiful scenery, and tasteful drama.

name: Douglas Wick, David Franzoni and Branko Lustig, Producers
Critic Review: While not everyone will be entertained by Gladiator's glum revenge story, Russell Crowe thunderously wins the crowd with a star-making turn that provides Ridley Scott's opulent resurrection of Rome its bruised heart.

name: Brian Grazer and Ron Howard, Producers
Critic Review: The well-acted A Beautiful Mind is both a moving love story and a revealing look at mental illness.

name: Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh and Barrie M. Osborne, Producers
film: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
Critic Review: Full of eye-popping special effects, and featuring a pitch-perfect cast, The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring brings J.R.R. Tolkien's classic to vivid life.

name: Martin Richards, Producer
Critic Review: A rousing and energetic adaptation of the Broadway musical, Chicago succeeds on the level of pure spectacle, but provides a surprising level of depth and humor as well.

name: Scott Rudin and Robert Fox, Producers
Critic Review: The movie may be a downer, but it packs an emotional wallop. Some fine acting on display here.

name: Barrie M. Osborne, Peter Jackson and Fran Walsh, Producers
film: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
Critic Review: Visually breathtaking and emotionally powerful,  The Lord of the Rings - The Return of the King is a moving and satisfying conclusion to a great trilogy.

name: Ross Katz and Sofia Coppola, Producers
Critic Review: Effectively balancing humor and subtle pathos, Sofia Coppola crafts a moving, melancholy story that serves as a showcase for both Bill Murray and Scarlett Johansson.

name: Samuel Goldwyn, Jr., Peter Weir and Duncan Henderson, Producers
film: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World
Critic Review: Russell Crowe's rough charm is put to good use in this masterful adaptation of Patrick O'Brian's novel.

name: Michael Mann and Graham King, Producers
Critic Review: With a rich sense of period detail, The Aviator succeeds thanks to typically assured direction from Martin Scorsese and a strong performance from Leonardo DiCaprio, who charts Howard Hughes' descent from eccentric billionaire to reclusive madman.

name: Clint Eastwood, Albert S. Ruddy and Tom Rosenberg, Producers
Critic Review: Clint Eastwood's assured direction - combined with knockout performances from Hilary Swank and Morgan Freeman - help Million Dollar Baby to transcend its clichés, and the result is deeply heartfelt and moving.

name: Michael London, Producer
Critic Review: Charming, thoughtful, and often funny, Sideways is a decidedly mature road trip comedy full of excellent performances.

name: Diana Ossana and James Schamus, Producers
Critic Review: A beautiful, epic Western, Brokeback Mountain's love story is imbued with heartbreaking universality thanks to moving performances by Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal.

name: Paul Haggis and Cathy Schulman, Producers
Critic Review: A raw and unsettling morality piece on modern angst and urban disconnect, Crash examines the dangers of bigotry and xenophobia in the lives of interconnected Angelenos.

name: Alejandro González Iñárritu, Jon Kilik and Steve Golin, Producers
Critic Review: In Babel, there are no villains, only victims of fate and circumstance. Director Alejandro Gonzalez Iñarritu weaves four of their woeful stories into this mature and multidimensional film.

name: Graham King, Producer
Critic Review: Featuring outstanding work from an excellent cast, The Departed is a thoroughly engrossing gangster drama with the gritty authenticity and soupy morality we come to expect from Martin Scorsese.

name: Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner and Paul Webster, Producers
Critic Review: Atonement features strong performances, brilliant cinematography, and a unique score. Featuring deft performances from James MacAvoy and Keira Knightley, it's a successful adaptation of Ian McEwan's novel.

name: Scott Rudin, Ethan Coen and Joel Coen, Producers
Critic Review: Bolstered by powerful lead performances from Javier Bardem, Josh Brolin, and Tommy Lee Jones, No Country for Old Men finds the Coen brothers spinning cinematic gold out of Cormac McCarthy's grim, darkly funny novel.

name: JoAnne Sellar, Paul Thomas Anderson and Daniel Lupi, Producers
Critic Review: Widely touted as a masterpiece, this sparse and sprawling epic about the underhanded "heroes" of capitalism boasts incredible performances by leads Daniel Day-Lewis and Paul Dano, and is director Paul Thomas Anderson's best work to date.

name: Christian Colson, Producer
Critic Review: Visually dazzling and emotionally resonant, Slumdog Millionaire is a film that's both entertaining and powerful.

name: James Cameron and Jon Landau, Producers
Critic Review: It might be more impressive on a technical level than as a piece of storytelling, but Avatar reaffirms James Cameron's singular gift for imaginative, absorbing filmmaking.

name: Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal, Nicolas Chartier and Greg Shapiro, Producers
Critic Review: A well-acted, intensely shot, action filled war epic, Kathryn Bigelow's The Hurt Locker is thus far the best of the recent dramatizations of the Iraq War.

name: Emma Thomas and Christopher Nolan, Producers
Critic Review: Smart, innovative, and thrilling, Inception is that rare summer blockbuster that succeeds viscerally as well as intellectually.

name: Gary Gilbert, Jeffrey Levy-Hinte and Celine Rattray, Producers
Critic Review: Worthwhile as both a well-acted ensemble piece and as a smart, warm statement on family values, The Kids Are All Right is remarkable.

name: Iain Canning, Emile Sherman and Gareth Unwin, Producers
Critic Review: Colin Firth gives a masterful performance in The King's Speech, a predictable but stylishly produced and rousing period drama.

name: Scott Rudin, Dana Brunetti, Michael De Luca and Ceán Chaffin, Producers
Critic Review: Impeccably scripted, beautifully directed, and filled with fine performances, The Social Network is a riveting, ambitious example of modern filmmaking at its finest.

name: Thomas Langmann, Producer
Critic Review: A crowd-pleasing tribute to the magic of silent cinema, The Artist is a clever, joyous film with delightful performances and visual style to spare.

name: Jim Burke, Alexander Payne and Jim Taylor, Producers
Critic Review: Funny, moving, and beautifully acted, The Descendants captures the unpredictable messiness of life with eloquence and uncommon grace.

name: Scott Rudin, Producer
Critic Review: Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close has a story worth telling, but it deserves better than the treacly and pretentious treatment director Stephen Daldry gives it.

name: Graham King and Martin Scorsese, Producers
Critic Review: Hugo is an extravagant, elegant fantasy with an innocence lacking in many modern kids' movies, and one that emanates an unabashed love for the magic of cinema.

name: Grant Heslov, Ben Affleck and George Clooney, Producers
Critic Review: Tense, exciting, and often darkly comic, Argo recreates a historical event with vivid attention to detail and finely wrought characters.

name: Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner, Debra Hayward and Cameron Mackintosh, Producers
Critic Review: Impeccably mounted but occasionally bombastic, Les Misérables largely succeeds thanks to bravura performances from its distinguished cast.

name: Gil Netter, Ang Lee and David Womark, Producers
Critic Review: A 3D adaptation of a supposedly "unfilmable" book, Ang Lee's Life of Pi achieves the near impossible -- it's an astonishing technical achievement that's also emotionally rewarding.

name: Charles Roven, Richard Suckle, Megan Ellison and Jonathan Gordon, Producers
Critic Review: Riotously funny and impeccably cast, American Hustle compensates for its flaws with unbridled energy and some of David O. Russell's most irrepressibly vibrant direction.

name: Alfonso Cuarón and David Heyman, Producers
Critic Review: Alfonso Cuarón's Gravity is an eerie, tense sci-fi thriller that's masterfully directed and visually stunning.

name: Brad Pitt, Dede Gardner, Jeremy Kleiner, Steve McQueen and Anthony Katagas, Producers
Critic Review: It's far from comfortable viewing, but 12 Years a Slave's unflinchingly brutal look at American slavery is also brilliant -- and quite possibly essential -- cinema.

name: Alejandro G. Iñárritu, John Lesher and James W. Skotchdopole, Producers
film: Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)
Critic Review: A thrilling leap forward for director Alejandro González Iñárritu, Birdman is an ambitious technical showcase powered by a layered story and outstanding performances from Michael Keaton and Edward Norton.

name: Richard Linklater and Cathleen Sutherland, Producers
Critic Review: Epic in technical scale but breathlessly intimate in narrative scope, Boyhood is a sprawling investigation of the human condition.

name: Wes Anderson, Scott Rudin, Steven Rales and Jeremy Dawson, Producers
Critic Review: Typically stylish but deceptively thoughtful, The Grand Budapest Hotel finds Wes Anderson once again using ornate visual environments to explore deeply emotional ideas.

name: Brad Pitt, Dede Gardner and Jeremy Kleiner, Producers
Critic Review: The Big Short approaches a serious, complicated subject with an impressive attention to detail -- and manages to deliver a well-acted, scathingly funny indictment of its real-life villains in the bargain.

name: Steven Spielberg, Marc Platt and Kristie Macosko Krieger, Producers
Critic Review: Bridge of Spies finds new life in Hollywood's classic Cold War espionage thriller formula, thanks to reliably outstanding work from Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks.

name: Finola Dwyer and Amanda Posey, Producers
Critic Review: Brooklyn buttresses outstanding performances from Saoirse Ronan and Emory Cohen with a rich period drama that tugs at the heartstrings as deftly as it satisfies the mind.

name: Doug Mitchell and George Miller, Producers
Critic Review: With exhilarating action and a surprising amount of narrative heft, Mad Max: Fury Road brings George Miller's post-apocalyptic franchise roaring vigorously back to life.

name: Simon Kinberg, Ridley Scott, Michael Schaefer and Mark Huffam, Producers
Critic Review: Smart, thrilling, and surprisingly funny, The Martian offers a faithful adaptation of the bestselling book that brings out the best in leading man Matt Damon and director Ridley Scott.

name: Arnon Milchan, Steve Golin, Alejandro G. Iñárritu, Mary Parent and Keith Redmon, Producers
Critic Review: As starkly beautiful as it is harshly uncompromising, The Revenant uses Leonardo DiCaprio's committed performance as fuel for an absorbing drama that offers punishing challenges -- and rich rewards.

name: Ed Guiney, Producer
Critic Review: Led by incredible work from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, Room makes for an unforgettably harrowing -- and undeniably rewarding -- experience.

name: Michael Sugar, Steve Golin, Nicole Rocklin and Blye Pagon Faust, Producers
Critic Review: Spotlight gracefully handles the lurid details of its fact-based story while resisting the temptation to lionize its heroes, resulting in a drama that honors the audience as well as its real-life subjects.

name: Shawn Levy, Dan Levine, Aaron Ryder and David Linde, Producers
Critic Review: Arrival delivers a must-see experience for fans of thinking person's sci-fi that anchors its heady themes with genuinely affecting emotion and a terrific performance from Amy Adams.

name: Scott Rudin, Denzel Washington and Todd Black, Producers
Critic Review: From its reunited Broadway stars to its screenplay, the solidly crafted Fences finds its Pulitzer-winning source material fundamentally unchanged -- and still just as powerful.

name: Bill Mechanic and David Permut, Producers
Critic Review: Hacksaw Ridge uses a real-life pacifist's legacy to lay the groundwork for a gripping wartime tribute to faith, valor, and the courage of remaining true to one's convictions.

name: Carla Hacken and Julie Yorn, Producers
Critic Review: Hell or High Water offers a solidly crafted, well-acted Western heist thriller that eschews mindless gunplay in favor of confident pacing and full-bodied characters.

name: Donna Gigliotti, Peter Chernin, Jenno Topping, Pharrell Williams and Theodore Melfi, Producers
Critic Review: In heartwarming, crowd-pleasing fashion, Hidden Figures celebrates overlooked -- and crucial -- contributions from a pivotal moment in American history.

name: Fred Berger, Jordan Horowitz and Marc Platt, Producers
Critic Review: La La Land breathes new life into a bygone genre with thrillingly assured direction, powerful performances, and an irresistible excess of heart.

name: Emile Sherman, Iain Canning and Angie Fielder, Producers
Critic Review: Lion's undeniably uplifting story and talented cast make it a moving journey that transcends the typical cliches of its genre.

name: Matt Damon, Kimberly Steward, Chris Moore, Lauren Beck and Kevin J. Walsh, Producers
Critic Review: Manchester by the Sea delivers affecting drama populated by full-bodied characters, marking another strong step forward for writer-director Kenneth Lonergan.

name: Adele Romanski, Dede Gardner and Jeremy Kleiner, Producers
Critic Review: Moonlight uses one man's story to offer a remarkable and brilliantly crafted look at lives too rarely seen in cinema.

name: Scott Rudin, Eli Bush and Evelyn O'Neill, Producers
Critic Review: Lady Bird delivers fresh insights about the turmoil of adolescence -- and reveals writer-director Greta Gerwig as a fully formed filmmaking talent.

name: Guillermo del Toro and J. Miles Dale, Producers
Critic Review: The Shape of Water finds Guillermo del Toro at his visually distinctive best -- and matched by an emotionally absorbing story brought to life by a stellar Sally Hawkins performance.

name: Graham King, Producer
Critic Review: Bohemian Rhapsody hits a handful of high notes, but as an in-depth look at a beloved band, it offers more of a medley than a true greatest hits collection.

name: Jim Burke, Charles B. Wessler, Brian Currie, Peter Farrelly and Nick Vallelonga, Producers
Critic Review: Green Book takes audiences on an excessively smooth ride through bumpy subject matter, although Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen's performances add necessary depth.

name: Gabriela Rodríguez and Alfonso Cuarón, Producers
Critic Review: Roma finds writer-director Alfonso Cuarón in complete, enthralling command of his visual craft - and telling the most powerfully personal story of his career.

name: Bill Gerber, Bradley Cooper and Lynette Howell Taylor, Producers
Critic Review: No consensus yet.

name: Dede Gardner, Jeremy Kleiner, Adam McKay and Kevin Messick, Producers
Critic Review: Vice takes scattershot aim at its targets, but writer-director Adam McKay hits some satisfying bullseyes -- and Christian Bale's transformation is a sight to behold.

name: Peter Chernin, Jenno Topping and James Mangold, Producers
Critic Review: Ford v Ferrari delivers all the polished auto action audiences will expect -- and balances it with enough gripping human drama to satisfy non-racing enthusiasts.

name: Martin Scorsese, Robert De Niro, Jane Rosenthal and Emma Tillinger Koskoff, Producers
Critic Review: An epic gangster drama that earns its extended runtime, The Irishman finds Martin Scorsese revisiting familiar themes to poignant, funny, and profound effect.

name: Carthew Neal, Taika Waititi and Chelsea Winstanley, Producers
Critic Review: Jojo Rabbit's blend of irreverent humor and serious ideas definitely won't be to everyone's taste -- but either way, this anti-hate satire is audacious to a fault.

name: Todd Phillips, Bradley Cooper and Emma Tillinger Koskoff, Producers
Critic Review: Joker gives its infamous central character a chillingly plausible origin story that serves as a brilliant showcase for its star -- and a dark evolution for comics-inspired cinema.

name: Amy Pascal, Producer
Critic Review: With a stellar cast and a smart, sensitive retelling of its classic source material, Greta Gerwig's Little Women proves some stories truly are timeless.

name: Noah Baumbach and David Heyman, Producers
Critic Review: Observing a splintering union with compassion and expansive grace, the powerfully acted Marriage Story ranks among writer-director Noah Baumbach's best works.

name: Sam Mendes, Pippa Harris, Jayne-Ann Tenggren and Callum McDougall, Producers
Critic Review: Hard-hitting, immersive, and an impressive technical achievement, 1917 captures the trench warfare of World War I with raw, startling immediacy.

name: Kwak Sin Ae and Bong Joon Ho, Producers
Critic Review: An urgent, brilliantly layered look at timely social themes, Parasite finds writer-director Bong Joon Ho in near-total command of his craft.

name: David Parfitt, Jean-Louis Livi and Philippe Carcassonne, Producers
Critic Review: Led by stellar performances and artfully helmed by writer-director Florian Zeller, The Father presents a devastatingly empathetic portrayal of dementia.

name: Shaka King, Charles D. King and Ryan Coogler, Producers
Critic Review: An electrifying dramatization of historical events, Judas and the Black Messiah is a forceful condemnation of racial injustice -- and a major triumph for its director and stars.

name: Ceán Chaffin, Eric Roth and Douglas Urbanski, Producers
Critic Review: Sharply written and brilliantly performed, Mank peers behind the scenes of Citizen Kane to tell an old Hollywood story that could end up being a classic in its own right.

name: Christina Oh, Producer
Critic Review: Led by arresting performances from Steven Yeun and Yeri Han, Minari offers an intimate and heart-wrenching portrait of family and assimilation in 1980s America.

name: Frances McDormand, Peter Spears, Mollye Asher, Dan Janvey and Chloé Zhao, Producers
Critic Review: A poetic character study on the forgotten and downtrodden, Nomadland beautifully captures the restlessness left in the wake of the Great Recession.

name: Ben Browning, Ashley Fox, Emerald Fennell and Josey McNamara, Producers
Critic Review: A boldly provocative, timely thriller, Promising Young Woman is an auspicious feature debut for writer-director Emerald Fennell -- and a career highlight for Carey Mulligan.

name: Bert Hamelinck and Sacha Ben Harroche, Producers
Critic Review: An evocative look at the experiences of the deaf community, Sound of Metal is brought to life by Riz Ahmed's passionate performance.

name: Marc Platt and Stuart Besser, Producers
Critic Review: An actors' showcase enlivened by its topical fact-based story, The Trial of the Chicago 7 plays squarely -- and compellingly -- to Aaron Sorkin's strengths.

name: Laura Berwick, Kenneth Branagh, Becca Kovacik and Tamar Thomas, Producers
Critic Review: A deeply personal project for writer-director Kenneth Branagh, Belfast transcends its narrative deficits with powerful performances and directorial craft.

name: Philippe Rousselet, Fabrice Gianfermi and Patrick Wachsberger, Producers
Critic Review: CODA's story offers few surprises, but strong representation and a terrific cast -- led by Emilia Jones' brilliant performance -- bring this coming-of-age story vividly to life.

name: Adam McKay and Kevin Messick, Producers
Critic Review: Don't Look Up aims too high for its scattershot barbs to consistently land, but Adam McKay's star-studded satire hits its target of collective denial square on.

name: Teruhisa Yamamoto, Producer
Critic Review: Drive My Car's imposing runtime holds a rich, patiently engrossing drama that reckons with self-acceptance and regret.

name: Mary Parent, Denis Villeneuve and Cale Boyter, Producers
Critic Review: Dune occasionally struggles with its unwieldy source material, but those issues are largely overshadowed by the scope and ambition of this visually thrilling adaptation.

name: Tim White, Trevor White and Will Smith, Producers
Critic Review: King Richard transcends sport biopic formulas with refreshingly nuanced storytelling -- and a towering performance from Will Smith in the title role.

name: Sara Murphy, Adam Somner and Paul Thomas Anderson, Producers
Critic Review: Licorice Pizza finds Paul Thomas Anderson shifting into a surprisingly comfortable gear -- and getting potentially star-making performances out of his fresh-faced leads.

name: Guillermo del Toro, J. Miles Dale and Bradley Cooper, Producers
Critic Review: While it may not hit quite as hard as the original, Guillermo del Toro's Nightmare Alley is a modern noir thriller with a pleasantly pulpy spin.

name: Jane Campion, Tanya Seghatchian, Emile Sherman, Iain Canning and Roger Frappier, Producers
Critic Review: Brought to life by a stellar ensemble led by Benedict Cumberbatch, The Power of the Dog reaffirms writer-director Jane Campion as one of her generation's finest filmmakers.

name: Malte Grunert, Producer
film: All Quiet on the Western Front
Critic Review: Both timely and timeless, All Quiet on the Western Front retains the power of its classic source material by focusing on the futility of war.

name: James Cameron and Jon Landau, Producers
Critic Review: Narratively, it might be fairly standard stuff -- but visually speaking, Avatar: The Way of Water is a stunningly immersive experience.

name: Graham Broadbent, Pete Czernin and Martin McDonagh, Producers
Critic Review: Featuring some of Martin McDonagh's finest work and a pair of outstanding lead performances, The Banshees of Inisherin is a finely crafted feel-bad treat.

name: Baz Luhrmann, Catherine Martin, Gail Berman, Patrick McCormick and Schuyler Weiss, Producers
Critic Review: The standard rock biopic formula gets all shook up in Elvis, with Baz Luhrmann's dazzling energy and style perfectly complemented by Austin Butler's outstanding lead performance.

name: Daniel Kwan, Daniel Scheinert and Jonathan Wang, Producers
Critic Review: Led by an outstanding Michelle Yeoh, Everything Everywhere All at Once lives up to its title with an expertly calibrated assault on the senses.

name: Kristie Macosko Krieger, Steven Spielberg and Tony Kushner, Producers
Critic Review: Part memoir, part ode to the power of the movies, The Fabelmans finds Steven Spielberg digging at the family roots that helped make him a beloved filmmaker -- and proves he hasn't lost his magic touch.

name: Todd Field, Alexandra Milchan and Scott Lambert, Producers
Critic Review: Led by the soaring melody of Cate Blanchett's note-perfect performance, Tár riffs brilliantly on the discordant side of fame-fueled power.

name: Tom Cruise, Christopher McQuarrie, David Ellison and Jerry Bruckheimer, Producers
Critic Review: Top Gun: Maverick pulls off a feat even trickier than a 4G inverted dive, delivering a long-belated sequel that surpasses its predecessor in wildly entertaining style.
